message.content: This question requires knowledge of cell structure. Cells are surrounded by a thin membrane called the cell membrane or plasma membrane, which helps to maintain their shape and structure. Option (A) is incorrect because viruses do not help cells retain their function. Option (B) is a play on words and not related to cell structure. Option (D) is a play on words and not related to cell structure.

This question requires knowledge about cell structure and the role of the cell membrane. The thin membrane that surrounds cells is responsible for maintaining their shape and preventing them from contorting into deformed shapes. Option (A) is incorrect because viruses are not typically helpful to cells, and they do not play a role in maintaining cell shape. Option (B) is incorrect because a prison cell wall does not exist in the context of cellular structure. Option (D) is incorrect because cells do not have a manual to guide them; their shape is determined by the structural components within them and the cell membrane.

This question requires basic knowledge about cell structure and the role of the cell membrane. The cell membrane acts as a barrier and provides structural support to the cell. It regulates the movement of molecules in and out of the cell, preventing cells from contorting into deformed shapes. Option (A) is incorrect because viruses are not helpful to cells in retaining their function. Option (B) is incorrect because prison cell walls are unrelated to the structure of cells in the human body. Option (D) is incorrect because cells do not have a Chilton's manual or any external guide.

The thin membrane that surrounds cells, known as the cell membrane or plasma membrane, acts as a barrier and provides structural support to cells, preventing them from contorting into deformed shapes. Option (A) is incorrect because viruses are not generally helpful to cells and can actually cause damage and disrupt cellular function. Option (B) is a play on words and not related to cellular biology. Option (D) is a reference to a car repair manual and not related to cellular structure and function.
